data.question: Who are the authors of the research article?
data.answer: Victor I. Ovcharenko, Elena V. Gorelik, Sergey V. Fokin, Galina V. Romanenko, Vladimir N. Ikorskii, Anna V. Krashilina, Vladimir K. Cherkasov, and Gleb A. Abakumov

data.question: What is the title of the research article?
data.answer: Ligand Effects on the Ferro- to Antiferromagnetic Exchange Ratio in Bis(o-Semiquinonato)copper(II)

data.question: What type of complexes were synthesized in the study?
What effect does an extra ligand have on the magnetic properties of the complex?
data.answer: An extra ligand coordinated to the metal atom produces a dramatic effect on the magnetic properties of the complex, changing the multiplicity of the ground state.

data.question: Is the energy of the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction between the odd electrons of the SQ ligands in the Cu(SQ)2 bischelate sensitive to the nature of the extra ligand?
What does the Cu(SQ)2 matrix act as according to the study?
data.answer: The Cu(SQ)2 matrix acts as a polyfunctional molecular sensor for the first coordination sphere of the central atom.

data.question: What software package was used for all DFT calculations reported in the study?
Does the presence of DABCO in the coordination sphere have a dramatic effect on the odd-electron density redistribution?
What is the effect of the axial displacement of the Cu atom from the plane of the CuO4 coordination unit?
data.answer: The axial displacement of the Cu atom from the plane decreases the contribution of Cu 3dxz to magnetic orbitals, affecting the efficiency of the antiferromagnetic exchange coupling channel between ligands.

data.question: Is the Cu(SQ)2 matrix sensitive to the occurrence of an extra ligand in the coordination sphere of Cu(II)?
What does the study conclude about the Cu(SQ)2 matrix?
data.answer: The study concludes that the Cu(SQ)2 matrix is an unusual type of molecular sensor operated by variation of the ferro- to antiferromagnetic exchange ratio.

data.question: What is the role of the Cu(II) in the complexes according to the study?
data.answer: The Cu(II) incorporates an extra ligand in its coordination sphere and provides a specific combination of intramolecular ferro- and antiferromagnetic exchange with two SQ ligands.

data.question: Was the structure of the complexes determined using X-ray analysis?
What is the impact of the extra ligand's nature and orientation on the efficiency of the exchange channels?
data.answer: The nature and orientation of the extra ligand significantly affect the efficiency of the exchange channels by causing odd-electron density redistribution in the antiferromagnetic exchange channel.

data.question: What does the study reveal about the interaction between magnetic orbital 2 of the Cu(SQ)2 complex and the orbitals of Py or DABCO?
data.answer: The interaction leads to decreased splitting between magnetic orbitals 1 and 2, lowering the efficiency of the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction channel.

data.question: Is the study supported by the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (RFBR)?
What is the effect of elongation of the Cu−O distances in the coordination unit?
data.answer: Elongation of the Cu−O distances leads to a significant decrease in the energy of the exchange interaction between the odd electrons of the SQ ligands, affecting the ferro- to antiferromagnetic exchange ratio.

data.question: What is the publication year of the research article?
Does the study provide CIF files for all complexes?
What is the main conclusion of the study regarding the Cu(SQ)2 matrix?
data.answer: The main conclusion is that the Cu(SQ)2 matrix is a unique molecular sensor that operates by varying the ratio of ferro- to antiferromagnetic exchange in response to the presence and nature of an extra ligand.
